replies.author: @purpuradraco3747
replies.text:
@GMN360 It wasn't that long ago the Halifax was literally trying to get customers, or I should say at that time, members, to leave them. Back in the early 90's I got a job with a 5hr+ round bus trip so really needed a car to cut that down by half. I'd worked there over a year, very secure job at that point, so went to the then building society that my first employer opened an account with for me, the Halifax. I'd never been in the red and while I was fairly young then my savings usually hovered at over a grand. So I asked to borrow 1200 quid to buy a used car. They took an hour, I assume to annoy me even more, to tell me no, but they'd change their mind if I had at least 1500 quid savings.  My savings were nearly that at the time and my salary was enough that within 2 years of this I bought a house, within 10 years of this owning it mortgage free so not like I was a risky borrower and for such a pittance too. Within weeks of this decision they told members that they'd start charging anyone with less than, I wanna say a grand, been a while, in their account. You read it right, they would charge people who had money in the bank for the privilege of transacting on their own cash! How many left them due to this, which was obviously their intent, what else could it have been.

Turned out that about a year or so later they stopped being a building society so had to pay members whose accounts were in the black. Clearly then, they deliberately incentivised people to take their small accounts elsewhere and clearly this profited the big money involved in buying shares.

Refused anything to do with them since. And they want people to believe they are morally unassailable to come down on the woke cult side? Well, yes, I can believe that a money grubbing, dishonest corporation is virtue signalling for woke cult ideology, suits them perfectly.

To add to the tale if anyone is not too bored yet, Yorkshire Bank, who I'd never had dealings with before and didn't have an account with took 10 mins to give me a loan for 2500 quid (I asked for more, got a better car). Told them exactly what happened at the Halifax up front too, wanted to expedite it all rather than waste another hr and when they checked my credit rating they were gobsmacked I'd been refused.

Then, some years later, I discovered my morally repugnant woke brother was showing off because he'd managed to borrow over 60k (all he admitted to, before discovering what I thought of him for it but I suspect he took more), mostly from Halifax, with no intention of paying it back. I see, once the pay outs weren't an issue they went to excessive lending that helped create the banking crisis. Just before he and his wife used some scheme to avoid the debt (which they incessantly complained about, as well as the state the UK was in due to the bank bailout, despite being let off the vast bulk of what they owed and despite their thievery helped create the banking crisis) they spent another 5k on a holiday, over 1k of which went on holiday clothes, ramping their debt up even more because immoral people take as much advantage as they can, don't they. What's worse, the Halifax let them borrow even more, why not when they obviously expected taxpayers to bail them out of any loses back then.

Socialism suits banks so well, think of all the advantages underwritten by a nanny state who would never let them sink.

I can only hope everyone calls them on their ultimatum, woke customers is what they deserve, no one else.

@huckleberryharrison6248 Because it's not the solution. The problem is not the problem, it's how we are told to think about the problem.
I had mild Gender Dysphoria as a young boy. I never *felt* like a girl, but I was more feminine, and enjoyed stereotypical girl things. I was surrounded by Adults, and other children, who perpetually bullied / harassed me for being feminine. Mousey, shy, artsy, long hair, etc. So I often wondered "I should have been born a girl."

As I got older, I got more into Stereotypical Male hobbies. I hunt, fish, I did 2 combat tours in Afghanistan, and work on cars, I do carpentry, etc etc. I also still have long hair, that I braid, I sew, and tailor most of my own clothes, I'll take a glass of red wine over a beer any day, and still do art and other "Female hobbies".

My depression / confusion went away when I *stopped* listening to other people and just accepted myself for who I am. A straight man, who happens to enjoy some girly hobbies. Which is perfectly OK. Just like it's perfectly fine, for a Tom Boy, girl, to like Sports, and other male activities. It doesn't make them a man, they just like stereotypical male Hobbies.

Tom boys, in general, are more accepted than feminine men, though.  Which is probably why you see more Male to female trans people, rather than the other way around.

Our regular health is very much tied to our sexual health for better or for worse. Messing with hormones weakens the immune system GREATLY. Promoting such an unhealthy activity as "medicine" is downright disgusting, and I thank God I did my homework and got better.

author: @alexiatrott2714
text:
My sister transitioned to a male, she was VERY unstable mentally, and my parents operated under the mentality ‚Äúwe either let her transition or she‚Äôll kill herself‚Äù, because she threatened my parents all the time with that. Many therapists kept affirming her desire, my parents even took her to see dr. levin (yes, the Rachel Levine serving as secretary of health) who not even more than 20 minutes of talking to my sister and parents was adamant she transition. 

Since then, she‚Äôs been on hormones, had a double mastectomy, and now got a hysterectomy. She will never have children (she didn‚Äôt want them, but the option is forever gone now), and the WORST Part is all of the severe health issues she‚Äôs having now, literally peeing blood and doctors have pulled her from the hormones only because they HAVE to. My parents are still disillusioned thinking this was all a good thing, but my sister is no better mentally, will forever be dependent on my parents not able to function in normal society, and will die young. This is not ok. Every single medical ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù they consulted should be stripped of their license.

replies.author: @alexiatrott2714

I know if my penis fell off I would let myself die.

replies.author: @alexiatrott2714
replies.text:
Guess I should update after a year. So things have remained the same. I love my sister and it's been uncomfortable every time my family talks about her because they have rose-tinted glasses on. She's moved out with her boyfriend, and I think her boyfriend's a very nice guy, is actually a good influence, but to this day my sister does not give me the impression of being healthy psychologically or physically.

My biggest thing is that her overall quality of life is and has been for a while, severely unhealthy. When you have a God-shaped hole in your heart, whether you're religious or not, something will fill it and gender identity is taking that place I believe. I grieve for the loss of my sister. I am about to have a baby, she has never reached out to me once. I will not lie to my child about my sister either, but I don't even think my sister would have any desire to be around my kid anyways. And to this, yes, I've called and tried to talk with her (never bringing up gender or anything, just trying to talk about her life and ask how she's doing, talk about what's going on) and maybe I just haven't tried hard enough, but when I stopped calling, she never called me.

So I do firmly believe this gender/queer ideology is designed to rip families apart and take advantage of vulnerable children. I have a younger brother who I have a great relationship with who's echoed some of my concerns and has had to grieve in his own way over what this did to our family and to his own childhood. So this always affects more people than one may realize.

Anyways, if you read all this, thanks. Bless you and your family, and I hope you never have to experience this in your own life.

replies.text:
I have a family member whose story is almost identical to the one you described. Be encouraged and always, always be praying for her. I know that may not be what some want to hear, but in my experience, it absolutely makes a difference. And don't be ashamed or embarrassed by her (I only say that because that's something the Lord had to root out of me - not implying you're the same way). Don't lie to her, but also be willing to hug her and look her in the eyes with love. She may be distancing herself from you now, but you may be surprised by how she reaches out later.

Sorry, long comment, but I feel the need to encourage others who watch their loved ones go down this road.

I can't speak for what path Tulip there took, but when I transitioned years ago, and others my age...it was a very lengthy, in depth process requiring years of gender therapy. In depth discussion of pros/cons, what to expect, what will change, what won't, able to soundly deal and recognize what won't change and what you won't experience...that there are still differences between you as a transperson and the biological gender you transition to. And the therapy was very in depth and exhaustive to explore any other possible causes or underlying issues that would be causing gender dysphoria. After that, and years of living as the opposite gender, then you got a letter of recommendation from a therapist to start HRT. For surgeries, it was a longer wait and needing two letters of approval from therapists confirming that transitioning would be the past path to treat dysphoria AFTER exhausting all other venues.

Removing that process has had devastating results. Its not about your sexuality, or what colors or activities you enjoy, it goes so much deeper than that. This new generation of therapists don't recognize that. The new generation of teachers ignore it. These kids don't understand it and treat it like a choice in an attempt to fit in and be edgy and special. Ever since trans became a trend, self deletion rates have sky rocketed. For the last few years my support group has seen an influx of detransitioners, all of them under 26 years old. Either they came to the conclusion they were trans due to teacher/parent/peer pressure and online forums, or their therapists, if they saw one, didn't try to explore other causes. A lot of teens going through puberty experience body dysphoria, which is completely different from gender dysphoria, but nowadays the two are lumped together. These detransitioners aren't told the whole truth, or what to expect, or what it really means to transition.

Gender and sexuality need to stay the fuck out of schools. Its playing with fire and setting kids up to ruin their lives trying to be part of the in crowd. For years now, books and documentaries about detransitioners and their regrets, their stories have been banned and not carried in stores. Try to raise awareness and get told you have internalized transphobia. As if.

Therapists are nutso-bonkers themselves.  These days, they promote this stuff, or they just confirm the bias of the patient over and over and over again.  

For instance:

I knew a lady (we are no longer friends, at all) who was, shall we say, bats in the belfry, cue up the calliope, green monkeys dancing C.R.A.Z.Y.
She saw dragons.  Don't dare tell her she didn't, dragons were real, dragons existed, she saw them and talked to them.
She saw faeries.  Faeries were real and faeries gave her advice.
No.  Really.  I'm not joking.
She had special powers, too, of course.  
This is a grown woman, in her late thirties.
When her favorite cat died (which is sad), she shaved off her eyebrows... as a sacrifice to Baast (Egyptial Cat God)... who she did not worship, but merely thought was cool.
She played bass.  Except she didn't.
She did reiki.  Except she didn't.
She did massage therapy.  Except she didn't.
A million "Fresh! New! Exciting!" things would just pop up in her life, be her obsession for six to eighteen months, and then sort of get brushed under the rug as never really having been a thing.
Then she decided, or was lead to decide, that she was suffering from dysphoria.  
In her thirties.
Now, let me be a little blunt here, but she was what the gay community calls a "F@g H@g" (old term, and not my term, but it gets the point across).  She adored all things yaoi and boy/boy.  Absolutely obsessed.  
So, really, what she wanted was to live out her fantasies through permanent surgery.  The alteration of her entire life, because it made her cha-cha wet.  Of course, she would tell you she had aaaaaaaalways felt this way, and that it was so obvious, and how terrible you were for questioning her life choices, you evil, evil bigot *HEX!!*
I'm convinced her therapist pushed her to this.  She had a therapist (several, I think), and, uh... Well, look up, read the wall of crazy.  Did the therapist help, do you think?
Or did the therapist(s?) actively harm?

I don't know what became of her, or her husband of, like, more than a decade.  I don't care to know.

replies.author: @magnuscarlsson9969
replies.text:
I acctually grew out of my desire to transition. Back when i was younger there was no treatments such as puberty blockers etc. I started to feel that i was supposed to be a girl already around the age of 7-8 and the school counselor sent me to a child psychologist. This woman i talked to was 100% sure i had gender dysphoria, which meant she got my parents involved. So both my psychologist and my parents was on board encouraging these ideas i had, I don't blame my parents since they where just supportive and didn't know better at the time. The doctor told them I had gender dysphoria and they felt it was best to listen to her. Until about the age of 15 i was quite androgynous and identified a a girl. 

I started attending a boarding school the same year as i turned 16. Puberty had hit it's high point, which at first made me feel devastated. Since i had left my old town, everyone who gave me both security and misery was gone. Which opened up a chance for me to get some new perspectives, hanging out with new friends helped me develop more confidence and as a result i started to feel comfortable just being a feminine guy. Then a few years later(21) my girlfriend became pregnant and that experience changed me alot. These days I'm pretty much a ordinary cis-male.

I agree that time is needed, since alot of things change as we grow up.

author: @Bunnyinthebasement
text:
You know how we look back at old medical practices that were cruel or just false, and we wonder how anyone could have believed them?

For example, Ignaz Semmelweis, the father of hand hygiene, worked at a hospital with 2 maternity clinics. The First Clinic had medical students working there; the Second, midwives. The First Clinic had a mortality fate infamously high that women begged on their knees not to be admitted there.

Long story short, Simmelweis figured out the medical students weren‚Äôt washing their hands after autopsies and would examine the pregnant women while contaminated. After he started making the students wash their hands, the mortality rate went down.

How was he rewarded? He was mocked by his scientific/medical peers who hadn‚Äôt germ theory at the time.

Medicine and science has many scenarios where false theories were accepted as facts and anyone who went against the accepted ‚Äúscience‚Äù was ignored, ostracized and/or ridiculed. This transition stuff will likely be yet another case study for future scientists and doctors of tragic, incorrect theories.

author: @theproofistrivial7677
text:
I went to Soren‚Äôs thread (and as a woman with breasts‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a horror show) and read the email thread she had with her clinic and honestly it‚Äôs not even far outside of the standards of medical care I‚Äôve received.

I have a baby and am on a lot of mom forums. My baby has never been sick but I‚Äôve seen moms dismissed when their babies turned out to have MENINGITIS, which can be fatal even if they were a couple of hours too late. You can die very quickly. These moms disregarded medical advice and took their babies to the ER where the meningitis was discovered. 

And as for me, I was put on my famous ADHD doctor‚Äôs drug regimen. Despite reporting suicidal ideation (I almost jumped into the subway) and depressive symptoms, he told me to just push through because he published several papers about this drug regimen, and I got the feeling he just wanted to file me away as another successful case. It‚Äôs like YEAH, the drug may take months to work. But jumping into the subway takes SECONDS. Is it really worth risking? Surely being able to finish a homework assignment in five hours instead of ten is not worth my life? I had to save myself and I refused to take a single other dose of this drug. 

Here‚Äôs a blurb about strattera. The side effect is not unknown.

‚ÄúThe Centre for Adverse Reactions Monitoring (CARM) has received a report of suicidal ideation in a patient taking atomoxetine. The patient experienced gradual onset of symptoms over the first six weeks of treatment, starting with tearfulness and increasing to self-harming and suicidal ideation. The patient recovered after atomoxetine was stopped.

Suicidal ideation was observed in clinical trials in children and adolescents (5/357 in the Strattera group compared to 0/851 in the placebo group). There was one report of suicidal behaviour in the Strattera group. All patients being treated with Strattera should be observed for emergence of suicidal thoughts or behaviours, especially during the initial few months of treatment or at times of dose change.

Families and caregivers of children and adolescents being treated with Strattera should be informed of the need to monitor these patients for emergence of suicidal thoughts or behaviours that may include signs of agitation, irritability or unusual changes of behaviour. If any of these symptoms develop, medical advice should be sought immediately.‚Äù

Sadly, a lot of doctors are just psychopaths who think we‚Äôre all stupid. They would rather you die than take up a second of their time.
